items.title: ‘We found 23,000 worms!’ The soil project bringing life back to the land
bullets: • Soil is the second largest carbon store after the oceans, but it’s being steadily degraded
• Deforestation, intensive agriculture, urbanisation and pollution have decimated the soil
• One farming community is pioneering a soil health project to show how organic regenerative agriculture can restore this vital ecosystem

items.title: What does patriotism mean to you?
bullets: • We want to know what stirs a sense of belonging in the place you call home

• Too often, patriotism has been used as a tool of division rather than unity - defined from podium rather than people

items.title: Found Footage Horror ‘Project Butterfly: Flatwoods’ Coming Halloween Night 2025!

• The further the students dig, the more they uncover the terrifying truths of this bunker

• Flight disruptions have become increasingly common due to staffing issues

items.title: Potentially diseased lab monkey on the loose after truck crash in Mississippi
bullets: • A truck carrying rhesus monkeys was involved in a wreck on Interstate 59 on Tuesday afternoon in Jasper County, Mississippi
• The monkeys were infected with several viruses including hepatitis C and Covid-19, according to the Jasper county sheriff’s department
• A representative from Tulane University in New Orleans shared a differing statement on the monkeys

items.title: ‘Catastrophic’ Hurricane Hits Jamaica as Risk of Climate Change-Fueled Tropical Storms Rises
bullets: • Melissa, a Category 5 hurricane with winds exceeding 180 miles per hour, made landfall midday Tuesday in Jamaica
• The hurricane hit the island as research shows climate change magnifying the destructive force of tropical cyclones
• The likelihood of a tropical cyclone becoming a major hurricane increased by 5 percent per decade from 1979 to 2017

items.title: SNAP cutoff could hurt Texas grocers and the rest of the economy, experts say
bullets: • The cutoff of benefits to 3.5 million Texans that depend on the program could have ripple effects beyond those directly affected
• Those who rely on SNAP to buy groceries for themselves and their families make up about 12% of all grocery sales nationwide
• Experts say the sudden loss of that income will mean SNAP recipients have less money to spend in Texas grocery stores

items.title: Ancient tides may have sparked humanity’s first urban civilization
bullets: • New research shows that the rise of Sumer was deeply tied to the tidal and sedimentary dynamics of ancient Mesopotamia
• Early communities harnessed predictable tides for irrigation, but when deltas cut off the Gulf’s tides, they faced crisis and reinvented their society
• This interplay of environment and culture shaped Sumer's myths, politics, and innovations
